prompt: <description>Part 1: Cylindrical Object with Central Hole and Smaller Holes Step 1: Create Coordinate System Create a new coordinate system with the Euler Angles [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and Translation Vector [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. Step 2: Draw the first face sketch 1. Begin by creating a circle at point [0.375, 0.375] with a radius of 0.375. This will be the base of the central hole of the cylindrical object. Step 3: Draw the second face sketch 1. Create a circle centered at point [0.0663, 0.375] with radius 0.0455. This defines the smaller hole in the outer circular region of the cylindrical object. Step 4: Draw the third face sketch 1. Create a circle whose center is at [0.375, 0.375] with a radius of 0.2462. This represents a central ring surrounding the central hole. Step 5: Draw the fourth face sketch 1. Create a circle with the center at [0.375, 0.0658] and radius of 0.0455. This defines the smaller hole in the lower circular region of the cylindrical object. Step 6: Draw the fifth face sketch 1. Create a circle situated at [0.375, 0.6852] with radius 0.0455. This corresponds to the smaller hole in the upper circular region of the cylindrical object. Step 7: Draw the sixth face sketch 1. Create a circle centered at [0.6857, 0.375] with radius 0.0455. This forms the smaller hole in the right circular region of the cylindrical object. Step 8: Scale and Extrude the Sketches 1. Scale the sketches by a factor of 0.75. 2. Extrude the first face sketch towards the normal by a depth of 0.0481 and without extruding it in the opposite direction. This will create the main body of the cylindrical object. 3. Extrude the second to sixth face sketches by a depth of 0.0481, aligned with the opposite direction of normals. This will create the smaller holes around the circumference of the cylindrical object. For reference, the shape of this intermediate part is a cylindrical object with a central hole and smaller holes distributed around the circumference. The length, width, and height of part 1 are 0.75, 0.75, and 0.0481, respectively, while the final shape's dimensions are determined by the assembly and mating of all the parts.</description>

Step 2: Draw a 2D sketch on the X-Y plane Create a new 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. You'll be creating a series of lines and arcs in a counter-clockwise direction. Line 3: Starting at (0.0957, 0.0), Ending at (0.0957, 0.0117). 4. Line 4: Starting at (0.0957, 0.3164), Ending at (0.0, 0.3164). Step 4: Create arcs Create the following arcs: 1. Step 6: Extrude the 2D sketch to create the 3D model Extrude the 2D sketch by 0.75 units along the Z-axis. This will create the final shape, which is a cylindrical object with a slightly tapered end.</description>
